sections.eyebrow: A more stable alternative to loose dentures
sections.title: A more stable alternative to loose dentures
sections.body:
Loose or unstable dentures can affect eating, speech, and confidence.

Implant-retained dentures use a small number of implants to help stabilise a denture, making it more secure, more comfortable, and easier to manage day-to-day.
bullets: Designed for comfort, function, and confidence

ctas.label: Plan a clinician-led implant retained dentures review

sections.title: How implant-retained dentures work
sections.body:
Typically:
- a small number of implants are placed
- the denture is designed to clip or locate onto them
- the denture can still be removed for cleaning

This approach improves stability while keeping maintenance manageable.

sections.title: Who may benefit
items: Want better stability without extensive surgery
Prefer a removable option for cleaning
Assessment is essential to confirm suitability.

sections.title: Planning before placement
items: Digital scans and imaging to assess bone and space
Evaluating bite forces and chewing patterns
Considering cleaning access and long-term maintenance
Planning the final tooth position before implants

sections.title: Alternatives and staging
sections.body:
In some cases, a staged approach is more sensible:
- starting with fewer implants
- using a removable option initially
- addressing gum health or bite issues first

We’ll explain when staging improves outcomes — and when it doesn’t.
items: Staging to reduce complexity where appropriate
Removable options as an interim step
Gum health and bite issues addressed early

sections.title: Aftercare, healing, and long-term care
items: Balanced risks: soreness, swelling, implant integration
Smoking and health considerations, discussed responsibly

faqs.question: How stable are implant-retained dentures?
faqs.answer: Implants provide anchor points that reduce movement and lifting, giving more stability than traditional dentures when planned and cared for correctly.

faqs.question: How many implants are needed?
faqs.answer: The number of implants is planned after assessment and scans, often fewer than a full fixed bridge requires while still providing reliable support.

faqs.question: Are they removable?
faqs.answer: Many implant-retained dentures are designed to be removed for daily cleaning while staying secure during eating and speaking. Suitability depends on your specific plan.

faqs.question: Will they feel bulky?
faqs.answer: The denture is crafted to balance stability with comfort. We review fit and make adjustments so it feels as natural and streamlined as possible.

faqs.question: Does the procedure hurt?
faqs.answer: Implant placement is carried out with local anaesthetic and a calm approach. Some pressure and post-treatment soreness are expected, with clear guidance to keep you comfortable.

faqs.question: How long do they last?
faqs.answer: Implants are intended for long-term use, but longevity depends on healing, home care, and attending regular reviews to monitor implant health and denture fit.

faqs.question: How much does treatment cost?
faqs.answer: Costs are discussed after a full assessment and planning stage, with transparent explanations of options so you know the investment before deciding.

faqs.question: Can I upgrade later to a fixed bridge?
faqs.answer: In some cases additional planning allows a transition to a fixed bridge later. We confirm if that pathway is realistic once we understand your bone health and goals.

sections.title: Fixed vs removable options
sections.body:
Some patients ask whether they should choose a fixed implant bridge instead.

The choice depends on:
- bone availability
- dexterity and cleaning ability
- budget and complexity
- personal preference

We’ll explain both routes clearly so you can decide confidently.

Our role is to help you choose a solution that improves comfort and function, fits your lifestyle, and can be maintained long-term.

Sometimes the simpler option is the better one.
